awd_titl_txt: Targeted Coordination of Dynamic Populations: Fundamentals, Computational Methods, and Emerging Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Complex systems that consist of populations of isolated or interacting dynamical components are prevalent in nature and human society. Notable examples of such systems include neural circuitry in the brain, metabolic chemical reaction systems in biology, and electrical power distribution, and traffic control systems in engineering. Tackling control and estimation tasks not only for one dynamical system but a whole population of a vast number of nearly identical dynamical units has thus emerged as a recurrent theme in numerous scientific and engineering areas, and the capability of precise targeted coordination and estimation of dynamic populations would open the floodgate to rapid and significant advancements in a diverse array of cutting-edge applications. The fundamental difficulty in dealing with dynamic populations is that control and observation can only be implemented at the population level, i.e., through broadcasting a single input signal to all the systems in the population, and through receiving aggregated measurements of the systems in the population, respectively, and there is a substantial lack of principled control and observation strategies for this new class of population systems. As a result, population-based technologies remain far from reaching their full potential. This research aims to establish a general and coherent theoretical and computational framework for the various emerging applications that critically rely on a targeted coordination of large populations of dynamical systems, and thereby close the current gap between theory and practice in the emerging applied problems concerned with population systems. The proposed investigation will promise new contributions to systems theory, control engineering, and biomedical and quantum technologies, and will in turn enhance the infrastructure for research and education across these disciplines. Concerted effort will be made to attract underrepresented groups and women to the research program and to engage the public and pre-college K-12 students in scientific research through the Institute for School Partnerships at Washington University.

This project will systematically investigate fundamental questions of controllability with respect to a broadcast signal, as well as observability with respect to aggregated measurements of the systems in the population and develop optimal control strategies that will enable a targeted coordination of dynamical structures in populations. By bridging formal systems theory, ensemble control techniques, applied algebra and geometry with computational engineering, general and versatile frameworks for population control will be formulated. Specifically, the control analyses and designs will be carried through by leveraging highly non-obvious yet fundamentally intimate links to different domains, including polynomial approximation for controllability and mathematical tomography for observability. The exploration of these novel connections will broaden the range of the theoretical and computational efforts for understanding the mechanisms and collective behavior of complex population systems and networks. Moreover, the developed theoretical and computational methods will be applied to analyze and control dynamic behaviors in population systems, including inducing synchronization patterns, decoding spatial and temporal information in complex networks, and revealing driving mechanisms of heterogeneous responses in cancer cell signaling networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Tackling control and estimation tasks not only for one dynamical system but a whole population of a vast number of similar dynamical units considered as one entity has recently been an emerging theme in numerous scientific and engineering areas. The fundamental challenge in dealing with such dynamic populations lies in the restrictions that control and observation can only be implemented at the population level, i.e., through broadcasting a single input signal to all the systems in the population, and through receiving aggregated measurements of the systems in the population, respectively. This project was initiated as a response to the lack of principled control and observation strategies for this new class of large-scale systems, which, at the time, meant that population-based technologies remained far from reaching their full potential.

With the conclusion of this project, we have established a general and coherent framework to address new theoretical questions and various applications that  are concerned with and critically rely on targeted coordination of large populations of dynamical systems. The development closed the current gap between theory and practice in controlling population systems. Through the integration of tools of algebraic topology, applied geometry, operator theory, and computational engineering, conditions of emergent fundamental system properties, including ensemble controllability with respect to a broadcast signal and ensemble observability with respect to aggregated measurements, were derived. In addition, optimal control strategies for effective coordination in population systems, such as synchronization and pattern formation, were also developed.  The exploration of these new concepts and tools broadened the range of the theoretical and computational advancement for understanding the mechanisms and collective behavior of complex population systems and networks. 

Beyond the novel development in systems and control, this project enabled and facilitated diverse cutting-edge applications in cell biology, neuroscience, and quantum technologies. It also resulted in the enhancement of infrastructure for research and education across these disciplines by systematically formalizing the study of dynamic population systems in interdisciplinary areas and developing advanced methods for optimal control design. These efforts led to innovative techniques for medical imaging, cancer treatments, and clinical neurostimulation. 

Multiple workshops, mini-symposia, as well as invited sessions in international conferences on the topics of control and learning for dynamical systems have been organized by the co-PIs in the control systems and applied mathematics societies. Efforts have been made to attract under-represented minorities and women to our research program. Independent study courses on special topics of control, computation, and learning of high-dimensional large-scale systems have been created and taught by the co-PIs at Washington University in St. Louis. The outreach effort is also continued to actively engage general public and pre-college K-12 students in scientific research through the university's science outreach and summer research programs.
